slides.title: The Information Retrieval Process
slides.subtitle: From User Need to Ranked Results

content.text: Understanding the complete lifecycle of a search query: how a user's vague information need is transformed, matched, and satisfied by an IR system.
content.hook: A search engine is a conversation between a user and a collection of documents.

content.text: The process begins with a user's 'Information Need'. This is distinct from the 'Query' they type. The gap between the two is often where retrieval fails.
content.definition: Information Need: A desire to locate and obtain information to satisfy a conscious or unconscious need.

slides.title: Types of IR Tasks
items: Ad-hoc Retrieval: Standard search (e.g., Google). One-time query on a static collection.
Filtering/Routing: Static query on a dynamic stream (e.g., News alerts).
Browsing: User navigates a structure (e.g., Directory) with no specific query.
Question Answering: Returning a specific fact rather than a document list.

slides.title: Text Operations (Preprocessing)
items: Lexical Analysis: Treating digits, hyphens, punctuation.
Thesaurus Expansion: Adding synonyms (e.g., car -> automobile).

content.hook: Ranking is what separates a search engine from a database.

slides.title: Check Your Understanding
questions: What is the difference between Ad-hoc retrieval and Filtering?
Why do we reduce documents to a 'Logical View'?
If a user wants 'apple' (the fruit) but types 'apple' (the brand), what kind of problem is this?
answers: Ad-hoc is a one-time query on a static collection, while Filtering is a static query (profile) on a dynamic document stream.
Computers cannot understand full text meaning efficiently; a 'Logical View' (keywords) allows for efficient indexing and matching.
It improves recall by matching variations of a word (e.g., 'fish', 'fishing', 'fished') to the same root query term.
